citation.article-title: Gracilibacillus halophilus sp. nov., a moderately halophilic bacterium isolated from saline soil.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Gracilibacillus halophilus sp. nov.
Gracilibacillus halophilus (ha.lo′phi.lus. Gr. n. hals salt; N.L. masc. adj. philus from Gr. adj. philos loving; N.L. masc. adj. halophilus salt-loving).
Cells are Gram-positive, catalase- and oxidase-positive, obligately aerobic, thin rods (4–8×0.3–0.5 μm) that occur predominantly in flexible chains (5–10 cells).
Cells are motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
Filamentous forms are present throughout the growth cycle.
They bear ellipsoidal endospores that lie in terminal swollen sporangia.
After 3 days on HSMA15 (pH 7.0) at 45 °C, colonies are circular, creamy white and translucent with slightly irregular margins and 1–1.5 mm in diameter.
No diffusible pigments are produced.
Growth occurs at pH 6.0–9.0 (optimum pH 7.0).
Moderately halophilic, with optimum growth at 15 % (w/v) NaCl and a growth range of 7–30 % (w/v) NaCl.
Moderately thermophilic, with optimum growth at 45–50 °C and a growth temperature range of 28–60 °C.
Positive for hydrolysis of chitin, aesculin, gelatin, starch and Tween 80, but negative for indole and H2S production, Voges–Proskauer and methyl red tests and hydrolysis of casein and urea.
Nitrate is reduced to nitrite.

Resistant to gentamicin (10 μg), kanamycin (30 μg), nalidixic acid (20 μg), polymyxin B (30 μg) and streptomycin (10 μg), but sensitive to ampicillin (30 μg), chloramphenicol (30 μg), lincomycin (2 μg), novobiocin (30 μg), rifampicin (5 μg) and tetracycline (30 μg).
Positive for oxidation of arabinose, inositol, sorbitol, amygdalin, rhamnose, sucrose and melibiose and fermentation of glucose, but negative for citrate utilization (API 20E).

Acids are produced from d-arabinose, d-ribose, d-tagatose, potassium 2-ketogluconate and potassium 5-ketogluconate and acids are produced weakly from d-glucose, glycogen, d-fructose, l-sorbose, l-rhamnose, inositol, d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, amygdalin, melibiose and sucrose (API 50CH).

Oxidizes acetic acid, amygdalin, l-arabinose, d-fructose, d-glucose, glycerol, glycogen, myo-inositol, maltose, d-mannitol, d-mannose, melibiose, raffinose, l-rhamnose, d-ribose, d-sorbitol, sucrose, trehalose, d-xylose, l-alanine and l-asparagine (Biolog GP2).

Constitutive enzymes expressed are alkaline phosphatase, esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), leucine arylamidase, cystine arylamidase, α-chymotrypsin, acid phosphatase, β-galactosidase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, α-glucosidase, β-glucosidase and α-mannosidase (API ZYM).
Menaquinone 7 (MK-7) is the predominant respiratory quinone.
The polar lipids consist of diphosphatidylglycerol and phosphatidylglycerol.
The major cellular fatty acids (making up 77.9 % of the total in the type strain) are iso-C15 : 0, C16 : 0, anteiso-C15 : 0, anteiso-C17 : 0 and C18 : 0.
Contains meso-diaminopimelic acid in the cell-wall peptidoglycan.
The genomic DNA G+C content of the type strain is 42.3 mol%.

The type strain, YIM-C55.5T (=DSM 17856T =CGMCC 1.6303T), was isolated from a saline soil sample collected from a beach of the Xiaochaidamu salt lake in the Qaidam Basin, Qinghai Province, north-west China.
